definitions.definition: to give a loud, high shout, because you are hurt, frightened, excited, etc.
definitions.sensetop: scream in/with somethingscream out in/with somethingscream outscream yourself + adj.

examples.text: There was a bang and I heard someone scream.
I wanted to run screaming from the room.
The kids were screaming with excitement.
I screamed in pain.
The man screamed in agony and collapsed.
He heard a few of the children screaming with laughter.
People ran for the exits, screaming out in terror.
The boy screamed out, as he felt a man's hand grab his arm.
The baby was screaming itself hoarse.
screaming fans
Despair shook him and he screamed silently in the darkness.
I was so bored I wanted to scream.
People were staggering about, screaming with pain.
People were screaming and yelling, passing out, fainting.

definitions.definition: to shout something in a loud, high voice because of fear, anger, etc.
definitions.sensetop: + speechscream (out) for something/somebodyscream at somebody to do somethingscream at somebodyscream something (out) (at somebody)scream (out) that…

examples.text: ‘Help!’ she screamed.
'Go away!' I screamed at the top of my voice *(= as loudly as possible)*.
Someone was screaming for help.
He screamed at me to stop.
examples.contextForm: scream at somebody to do something

examples.text: Everyone started screaming at each other.
She started screaming and shouting at me.
He screamed hysterically at me.
She screamed abuse at him.
She screamed out abuse at him.
I started pounding on the door screaming my lungs out *(= as loud and long as possible)*.
He **screamed his head off** *(= screamed very loudly and angrily)* at me.
His sister screamed out that he was crazy.
Marion screamed after them, ‘Stop! Stop!’
She screamed at me to get out of the way.

definitions.definition: to make a loud, high noise; to move fast, making this noise

examples.text: Lights flashed and sirens screamed.
The powerboat screamed out to sea.

definitions.definition: if you drag somebody kicking and screaming to do something, they only do it with great protests because they don't really want to do it at all

examples.text: The president had to be dragged kicking and screaming to the signing ceremony.

definitions.definition: to scream loudly and for a long time, especially in order to protest about something

wordOrigin: Middle English: origin uncertain; perhaps from Middle Dutch.
